summary: The family comedy "A Christmas Story Christmas" is the long-awaited follow-up to annual holiday favorite, "A Christmas Story."  This time, Ralphie is all grown up and must deal with Christmas and all that comes with it... as a dad. Peter Billingsley returns to the role that has made kids of all ages anticipate Christmas morning like no other.

And I'm not sure what I imagined Ralphie's childhood friends ending up doing with their lives, but getting pass-out hammered in a rundown dive bar every day definitely wasn't a guess. In fact, this film has a strange focus on binge drinking. I do realize it takes place in the 70s, but the constant boozing felt out of place and at odds with the chaste, wholesome vibes I expected. I'm no prude, but if I wanted to watch disenfranchised people drown their sorrows in cheap liquor and lament their disappointing lives, I'd go to Applebees. Review: A Christmas Story Christmas 

A Christmas Story Christmas is a genuine treat, a gift for those of us who have grown up with the beloved Bob Clark original. 

The story - set in the early 70's - follows a grown Ralph Parker ( a returning Peter Billingsley, who assumes narration duties from Jean Shepherd, on whose writings the original was based) revisiting the familiar house on Cleveland Street with his wife and children after a phone call from his mother delivers extremely sad news:  The Old Man has passed away.

The rest of the film chronicles Ralph's efforts to give his family the same holiday experience the Old Man always seemed to do with ease, only to discover how infrequently it's as easy as it looked when he was a boy . Along the way he reunites with Schwartz, Flick and even his old bully Scott Farkus. 

Many people may not be aware of this but between television films, direct to video sequels and an unsuccessful theatrical sequel directed by Bob Clark himself, A Christmas Story Christmas is roughly the eighth project inspired by Shepherd's work. 

It's also the best since A Christmas Story. What sets this film apart is the approach. This is as much a love letter to the original as it is a sequel and it really feels as if we're revisiting this charming cinematic world forty years on. 

The cast is excellent across the board, with Billingsley providing a strong center.  It helps that the actors portraying Schwartz, Flick, Farkus and even Ralph's younger brother Randy were brought back to portray their older selves. It feels like a homecoming and that chemistry quickly reestablishes itself.

If there's one aspect of the film that's different, it's the structure. Though this movie still has a through line of comedy, it leans a bit more to the dramatic side of things than its predecessor, particularly in regards to dual subplots about both Ralph's attempt to write an epic science fiction novel and his struggle to find the correct words to summarize his father in an obituary. The way these two threads eventually dovetail is as sweet as it is rewarding. Expect to go through some emotions as the film unfolds. It's impressive how well those heart tugging scenes sneak up on the viewer. The moment Ralph learns of his Dad's passing is particularly potent as - for a moment - we see in Billingsley's face that same young boy who smiled lovingly at his father upon realizing the Old Man had come through with a Red Ryder BB gun all those years ago. 

That said, the film does boast some genuinely funny moments. There are a few reasons for this.

One is the humor is relatable, only now it's relatable to those of us who grew up with the original because we're adults roughly the same age as Ralph and that's the perspective we experience Christmas from.

Another is the use of callbacks peppered throughout the film. A Christmas Story Christmas understands how to incorporate callbacks better than any movie I've ever seen. These are not cheap rehash moments. These are functional, such as years of resentment over the  tongue on the frozen pole schoolyard incident leading to an all new challenge being presented or the fact that Ralph still tends to drift into daydreams even as an adult ( an early example set in a publisher's office is very, very funny) .

But if there's a singular point from which the real comedic genius of this film originates, it has to be Julie Hagerty, who takes over the role of Ralph and Randy's mom from Melinda Dillon ( who retired from acting in 2007).

Honestly, I was concerned when  I read Hagerty was in this. I enjoyed her in the Airplane! movies, but Melinda Dillon was one of the best things about A Christmas Story. I wasn't sure Hagerty was a good fit.

I needn't have worried. Not only does the actress deliver the goods when the story calls for her to be serious, Hagerty proves she still has excellent comic timing and delivery, aided by a screenplay that allows her to be at times endearingly condescending or, alternately, delightfully weird.  She and Billingsley are the MVP's here without question. The scene where we find out what they really think about Christmas carolers is brilliant. 

I've been sick for a day or two having apparently caught something over the Thanksgiving holiday and I wasn't feeling well when I got around to watching A Christmas Story Christmas.  Despite that, by the time the end credits began to roll, I was grinning from ear to ear and I felt really good inside.

This is an excellent, honorable legacy sequel. It won't replace A Christmas Story, but it will earn a place next to it as part of my annual holiday veiwing line up moving forward. It's really rewarding to see someone still knows how to make a warm, funny holiday film that bears the message family, friends and above all love are what's most important. In this cynical age, that's a breath of fresh air. 

In embracing its gentle and nostalgic soul, A Christmas Story Christmas proves that even decades later, you really can go home again.

- D. S. Ullery

A Christmas Story (1983) is a perennial classic I watch every year. I own the DVD (just in case the cable goes out and I can't watch it on TBS or stream it on demand). It is a holiday tradition.

Sequels, on the other hand, are hard to pull off and have a lot to live up to. A Christmas Story Christmas has proven the old maxim, "You can't go home again," by literally attempting to do that very thing.

With the exception of them being older, nothing has changed on Cleveland Street after thirty-three years (outside of the old man's passing). And that's the problem. Even that life-altering event doesn't stop them from being holly jolly. All mom has to say is your father wouldn't want you to be sad; so let's enjoy Christmas and that's pretty much it.

So, in lieu of mourning the patriarch's death, they go by Higbees to see the store window, and inside the Santa exhibit is exactly the same. The Bumpuses still have the hound dogs. The visit to the tree lot is mandatory, they sing Jingle Bells in the car (though it's the Batman version because it's 1973, so that's change). The old man dying is a macguffin so they can revisit the old haunts and old stories.

I realize that for nostalgia buffs this is just fine. But thirty-three years have passed and old haunts usually close or are not there anymore. And old stories have already been told. And while the original movie revolved around the world of kid-dom at Christmastime, and that made it magical and wonderful, kids grow up, and "things get complicated when you get past eighteen…."

Personally, I would have liked to have seen Higbees turned into a casino (which it is IRL) with a Santa exhibit with showgirls or maybe it winds up in a state of decline (no more store window display and a meager Santa exhibit), maybe the Bumpuses win the lottery and move away and a hippie commune moves in next door. You know, things that show the passage of three decades.

As far as the old man dying at Christmas, c'mon. At least set it up where it is a year after the old man's death and since you hardly celebrated Christmas at all last year (you know, because your dad died), this year you're gonna go all out.

A Christmas Story Christmas did have some good moments (the best being the well placed homage in the last scene - bravo).

However, just like the passing of the old man, after one viewing I think I'll be closing the lid on A Christmas Story Christmas and letting it rest in peace. C-

39 years later we get a sequel to the timeless holiday classic, A CHRISTMAS STORY. Set in 1973, Ralphie (Peter Billingsley) has made a deal with his wife to quit his 9-5 job for the year to focus on his writing. However, if he doesn't get published before the year is over, he'll go back to the grindstone in 1974. With only 5 days before Christmas, the family makes the trip from their home on the south side of Chicago to Ralphie's old home in Hohman, Indiana where Ralphie is deputized by his mother to take over the Christmas planning. Bearing the weight of the stress of waiting to hear back from a publisher before the year's out and taking over Christmas duties, Ralphie and his wife Sandy (Erinn Hayes) do their best to navigate the pitfalls they must continually overcome until Christmas day. Let's be honest, it's nearly impossible to recreate the magic the original 1983 film accomplished as it's such a revered film, but this is a very touching sequel that stands on its own and doesn't besmirch it's predecessor. The role of Ralphie's mom has been recast from Melinda Dillon to Julie Hagerty but outside of that, everyone else has reprised there roles and there are a number of cameos. I'm confident in saying the world didn't need a sequel to A CHRISTMAS STORY as the original is ageless, but this is a worthy enough follow-up.

Admittedly, my bar was in the basement for this movie, but I was truly surprised by how moved I was by it. If you were in an "A Christmas Story" family like I was growing up - and that movie is wrapped up in your version of that childhood concept of Christmas that you lose somewhere along the way - this movie will speak to you.

What I really appreciated is that this movie is honest; it may occasionally try, but this isn't "A Christmas Story," and the movie knows it. The childhood magic and fantasy of Christmas transforms into a labor of love in adulthood, and this movie is about how Ralph (yeah, he's "Ralph" now... except to those who know him best) has an incredible labor ahead of him. And yet, just like Ralph still indulges in the occasional dissociative fantasy, we can still find moments to indulge in the fantastical pieces of Christmas in between budgeting for gifts and cleaning up the pine needles, no matter how old we are.

For many (most?) adults, Christmas joy becomes intermingled with Christmas sorrow at some point. You will have a particularly bad Christmas one year. You will notice who is missing. You will be disappointed in someone you love, or maybe they will be disappointed in you. "A Christmas Story Christmas" makes all of that clear, but it also makes clear that we can honor that sorrow while still finding ways to live in wonder and cheer. We just have to choose it.

I wouldn't leave it on my TV for 24 hours on Christmas day, but I do recommend it for any other day of the Christmas season.

A few other, more random thoughts: The bulk of the original cast is here again, sometimes in unexpected places. There are definitely moments where these characters are doing what they do for the nostalgia, or they're bringing closure to something we've already moved on from, or they're here just because, but I'm honestly glad so many of them are here again.

Mrs. Parker is the only character who has been recast. Julie Hagerty replaces Melinda Dillon in the role, and she was quite good. The differences are certainly noticeable - the script leans in to Hagerty's comedic chops - but it works perfectly well, and you will still probably have to look at her for a minute to really notice the difference at the start of the movie.

There are many sendups to the original, and though they feel somewhat silly at times (Ralph the Man still publicly engages in maladaptive daydreaming in front of other people while Flick and Schwartz are still triple-dog-daring one another), I think they work well. They lend themselves nicely to the tone of the film and feel pretty organic; again, this movie is pretty self-aware, so most of these are tongue-and-cheek references. That said, they're not overdone; they enhance the story, but they don't carry it.

Also, this is a reminder that his name is actually "Scut," not "Scott."

As the title suggests, this movie is the sequel to A Christmas Story, nearly 40 years in the making! It isn't necessary to watch the original movie to make sense of this one; however, there are references to the original movie that may be a bit confusing for those who haven't viewed it. Also, A Christmas Story is one of my favorite Christmas movies and is a joy to watch, so I do recommend it before watching this one if possible. One of my favorite parts of this movie is the fact that most of the original cast members play their same characters. Flick (Scott Schwartz), Schwartz (R. D. Robb), Randy (Ian Petrella), and even Scut Farkus (Zack Ward) all make an appearance. It is surreal (in a good way) to see what these former childhood actors now look like all grown up. I've never searched for their current appearances, so they are all a pleasant surprise. I also love how the sequel stays true to the original movie with all the sets, transitions and personalities of the characters. The narration is even similar to the first movie. Peter Billingsley, on top of just acting in this movie, also co-wrote and produced it. Kudos to him for all the work he did to bring us this movie. Speaking of some of the actors, my favorite performances are from Peter Billingsley (Ralphie), Julie Hagerty (Ralphie's mom) and Erinn Hayes (Sandy). Peter Billingsley keeps all his mannerisms and quirks from Ralphie even in his adult years, which makes this movie feel familiar and comedic. Julie Hagerty replaces Melinda Dillon as Ralphie's mom, and she fills her shoes so well. Erinn Hayes plays the newly introduced character Sandy and fits right in. She makes me feel as if she has been there forever because of the amusing interactions she has with other characters. The actors have so much chemistry, no doubt due to the fact that most of them have known each other for so long.

The primary message of A Christmas Story Christmas is that sometimes, it's the thought (and effort) that counts. This movie also deals with the loss of loved ones. There is some mild profanity and consumption of alcohol.
